name: Daily Inspiration
description: Start your day with motivational quotes from visionary leaders and thinkers.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: The only way to do great work is to love what you do.
quotes.notes: Verified from Stanford University's official transcript of Jobs' commencement address. This quote appears in the second story of his speech about love and loss.

quotes.content: In the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.
quotes.notes: This is a paraphrase. The original German from a 1949 letter reads closer to 'in the midst of every crisis, lies great opportunity.' Widely attributed but exact source disputed.

quotes.content: Believe you can and you're halfway there.
quotes.notes: Commonly attributed to Roosevelt but no verified primary source exists. Consistent with his philosophy of the 'strenuous life' and self-belief.

quotes.content: The future belongs to those who believe in the beauty of their dreams.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Eleanor Roosevelt. Appears in various collections of her quotes, though exact original source is difficult to verify.

quotes.content: It does not matter how slowly you go as long as you do not stop.
quotes.notes: Traditional attribution to Confucius. The sentiment aligns with Confucian philosophy of steady self-cultivation, though exact original text varies in translation.

quotes.content: Everything you've ever wanted is on the other side of fear.
quotes.notes: Attributed to real estate developer George Addair. The exact origin and date remain unverified, but the quote has been consistently attributed to him since at least the 1990s.

quotes.content: The only impossible journey is the one you never begin.
quotes.notes: Consistent with Tony Robbins' motivational philosophy. Used in his seminars and writings on personal development.

quotes.content: What lies behind us and what lies before us are tiny matters compared to what lies within us.
quotes.notes: Frequently attributed to Emerson but not found in his published works. May have originated from Henry Stanley Haskins' 'Meditations in Wall Street' (1940) or similar sources.

quotes.content: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Churchill but no verified source in his speeches or writings. The sentiment aligns with his wartime rhetoric about perseverance.

quotes.content: The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is now.
quotes.notes: Traditional Chinese proverb. Exact origin unknown but the wisdom about taking action has been passed down for generations.

quotes.content: I have not failed. I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work.
quotes.notes: Various versions exist. Edison did make similar statements about his iterative approach to invention, particularly regarding the light bulb. Verified through multiple biographies.

quotes.content: Whether you think you can or you think you can't, you're right.
quotes.notes: Consistently attributed to Ford and aligns with his philosophy on self-belief. Found in various collections of his quotes, though exact original context varies.

quotes.content: The greatest glory in living lies not in never falling, but in rising every time we fall.
quotes.notes: Often attributed to Mandela but actually paraphrased from Oliver Goldsmith. Mandela may have used a version of this sentiment in speeches.

quotes.content: Life is what happens when you're busy making other plans.
quotes.notes: From Lennon's song written for his son Sean. The line was inspired by earlier variations of this sentiment from other sources.

quotes.content: The only person you are destined to become is the person you decide to be.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Emerson and consistent with his transcendentalist philosophy of self-reliance and personal choice.

quotes.content: Don't watch the clock; do what it does. Keep going.
quotes.source: In One Era and Out the Other (1973)
quotes.notes: Verified from Levenson's book of humorous observations and wisdom. Levenson was an American humorist and writer.

quotes.content: Act as if what you do makes a difference. It does.
quotes.notes: Attributed to William James, the father of American psychology. Consistent with his pragmatist philosophy about the power of belief and action.

quotes.content: What you get by achieving your goals is not as important as what you become by achieving your goals.
quotes.notes: From Ziglar's influential personal development book. Ziglar was a renowned motivational speaker who influenced generations of self-help philosophy.

quotes.content: You miss 100% of the shots you don't take.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to hockey legend Wayne Gretzky. Popularized further when used by Michael Scott in The Office, often leading to the joke attribution 'Wayne Gretzky - Michael Scott.'

quotes.content: It always seems impossible until it's done.
quotes.notes: Commonly attributed to Mandela during his post-prison years. The sentiment reflects his experience of the seemingly impossible task of ending apartheid.

quotes.content: The way to get started is to quit talking and begin doing.
quotes.notes: Attributed to Walt Disney and consistent with his action-oriented philosophy. Used in Disney company materials and biographies.

quotes.content: If you want to lift yourself up, lift up someone else.
quotes.notes: Attributed to the educator and advisor Booker T. Washington. Consistent with his philosophy of self-improvement through community service.

quotes.content: You are never too old to set another goal or to dream a new dream.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to C.S. Lewis but no verified source in his published works. The sentiment is consistent with his later life writings on hope and renewal.

quotes.content: Do what you can, with what you have, where you are.
quotes.notes: From Roosevelt's autobiography. He attributes a similar sentiment to Squire Bill Widener, making this a paraphrase he popularized.

quotes.content: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.
quotes.notes: From Chapter 64 of the Tao Te Ching. Various translations exist; some translate the key character as 'step' while others use 'foot.'

quotes.content: Keep your face always toward the sunshineâ€”and shadows will fall behind you.
quotes.notes: Commonly attributed to Whitman though not found in his published poetry collections. May be a paraphrase of his optimistic philosophy.

quotes.content: In the end, it's not the years in your life that count. It's the life in your years.
quotes.notes: Frequently attributed to Lincoln but likely originated from an advertisement by Edward J. Stieglitz in the 1940s. No verified Lincoln source.

quotes.content: Start where you are. Use what you have. Do what you can.
quotes.notes: Attributed to tennis champion and activist Arthur Ashe. Reflects his philosophy of making the best of circumstances, especially during his civil rights advocacy.

quotes.content: The secret of getting ahead is getting started.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Twain but no verified source in his writings. The sentiment aligns with his pragmatic humor and philosophy.

quotes.content: Hardships often prepare ordinary people for an extraordinary destiny.
quotes.notes: Commonly attributed to Lewis but not verified in his published works. The sentiment is consistent with themes in his Christian apologetics and Narnia series.
